tool.name: RasterRanger

param.name: cycles
param.dialogReference:
Number of cycles (integer) (Default is one cycle, maximum is 10 [ArcMap limit])

To see more detail, you can either increase the number of cycles, or change range_min and range_max to make the displayed range smaller.

param.name: range_min
param.dialogReference:
Values outside this range will not be drawn. The default value is the minimum of the input raster.

To see more detail, you can either increase the number of cycles, or change range_min and range_max to make the displayed range smaller.

param.name: range_max
param.dialogReference:
Values outside this range will not be drawn. The default value is the maximum of the input raster.

If the Cycle Length is specified, the number of cycles usually will not cover the entire data range from min to max. In this case a warning message is displayed in the dialog showing the maximum value that will be displayed.

param.name: exclude_zero
param.dialogReference: If checked: zero raster values will not be displayed in the output layer.

tool.summary: This tool displays an unwrapped IfSAR raster in ArcMap using cycles of color. The tool classifies the data using a linear stretch (equal interval) of values between user specified min and max range.
tool.usage:
To add the style to the map:

Go to Customize > Style Manager, click Styles..., click Add Style to List, navigate to InSARToolsArcMap select Fringes.style, click OK.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This tool displays an unwrapped IfSAR raster in ArcMap using cycles of color. The tool classifies the data using a linear stretch (equal interval) of values between user specified min and max range.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: Dr. Kurt Katzenstein developed this method of displaying interferograms in ArcGIS. Python tool implementation by Curtis Price, South Dakota Mines, curtis.price@sdsmt.edu
